div1.ab:
Analyze
of the General Act of Brussels
The Governor of the Côte d'Ivoire, Mister Minister of the Colonies 1st Direction 1st Office
div1.p:
Mister Minister,
To respond to the observations contained in your dispatch from last March 7th, I have the honor of addressing to you the present report on the application, in the Colony of article 82 of the General Act of Brussels July 1890.
In that which concerns the treatment of blacks, I can only the of my report of the month of January 189 slavery does not exist on the territories that compose the Colonies.

Today that the posts are established in the interior of a of 200 Kilometers of the Coast, no no selling of captives was signaled to me by the administrators that only have to serve very rarely for the of authority towards the domestics.
Furthermore an active surveillance is exercised, on the coast of on the engagements of indigenous workers
that are under the control of the local Administration.
One can affirm that, To one side the poorness of treatment and the shots to flint , the introduction of arms and munitions to the Côte d'Ivoire, is only possible by the border of Liberia.

Finally, the rights on imported alcohol stayed at the same rate as the preceding year, and I will add that I make all my efforts auprès with the traders so that they attempt to subsitute of bad quality that of wine to which the indigenous would habituate easily.
I am, with the most profound respect, Mister Minister. Your very obediant servant. LG Binger
